title: We graded every team’s 2025 Giro d’Italia
content:
Cyclist
We graded every team’s 2025 Giro d’Italia

After the heroics of Simon Yates’s coup on the Finestre, we’ve finally managed to digest a stellar 2025 Giro d’Italia.

Yes, the Visma-Lease a Bike leader claimed the overall title, almost four minutes ahead of young gun Isaac del Toro in second and 2019 winner Richard Carapaz in third. However, the GC results are not the only thing that defines a team’s performance at a Grand Tour. Plenty of squads came into this race with ambitions of sprint glory, breakaway antics or simply a chance of getting on TV.

Out of the 23 teams that started the Giro d’Italia, 11 claimed stage wins, 15 teams were represented inside the top 20 of the overall rankings and six ended up winning special prizes in Rome. Elsewhere, 11 teams scored over 1,000 UCI points and ten squads managed to accrue more than €50,000 in prize money.

Now that we’ve let the dust settle on the 108th Giro d’Italia, we’ve put together a report card for every team. To settle on our scores from A to F, we’ll factor in roster strength, pre-race ambitions, results and visibility throughout the race.

Alpecin-Deceuninck: B

Alpecin-Deceuninck got what they came here for. By that, I mean a sprint stage victory.

Yes, Kaden Groves continued the Belgian team’s incredible victory streak, with another win to add to their books on a rainy day in Naples. After that, he continued to get stuck in at the head of sprint finales, with two further podium finishes.

Otherwise, the squad were present in breakaways when they had the resources. Quinten Hermans and Groves were off the front of the race on several occasions – most notably the gravel stage – but no additional wins would come their way. In all fairness, it’s tough for a sprint team to claim a win outside the flatlands, but Alpecin-Deceuninck certainly filled their customary role as a reliable pack of rouleurs and fastmen.

Arkéa-B&B Hotels: F

If anyone can recall one highlight from Arkéa-B&B Hotels’ Giro d’Italia, I’ll give you a fiver.

Their silence has been almost deafening throughout the three weeks. There has been no ambition in the breakaways, no attempts on the sprints, and nothing to write home about. Alessandro Verre almost gave me the right to crack an egg on my face on Stage 20, but otherwise the squad had an enormous lack of impact in the race mechanics.

There is some praise to be handed to the 22-year-old Embret Svestad-Bårdseng, who finished in 22nd place in the overall standings. Although this was a solid result for a rider no one had heard of three weeks ago, I would have expected more from a team on the cusp of WorldTour relegation.

Bahrain Victorious: B-

Bahrain Victorious have been one of the strongest teams in recent Giro history. They’ve reached the podium, won the points jersey and claimed plenty of stages in recent years. This season they were solid once again but not quite as prevalent as before.

For most of the first two weeks, Antonio Tiberi looked set for a top ten finish. While in third place overall the Italian’s Giro came crumbling down after a heavy crash and time loss on Stage 14. He would soon feel the effects of the tumble and drop down the standings even further in the final week. With Tiberi out of sight, Damiano Caruso would soldier on to another top five finish at the Giro, his third in four years. Without that result, it would have been tough to praise this team at all.

Although Bahrain secured another top GC result, the squad has failed to win a stage, continuing a drought in the Grand Tours stretching from the 2023 Vuelta. With that, we can consider Bahrain’s race to be bang average for a team of its budget.

Cofidis: D

I had to remind myself on several occasions that Cofidis were actually at the Giro d’Italia.

Yes, they brought a secondary list of riders, with the Tour de France taking priority – especially as it starts in their home region of Lille. And yes, they started on the right foot, as Sylvain Moniquet had a brief stint in the blue jersey. However, the other noteworthy results were few and far between. Milan Fretin proved that he wasn’t a Coupe de France flash in the pan, but otherwise the squad could have done better.

Cofidis’s best rider in the GC was in 52nd place (Sergio Samitier). Fretin scored two top tens, peaking with a runners-up spot on Stage 6. Apart from that, the team were rarely seen on the top half of the results sheet.

Decathlon-AG2R La Mondiale: C

Last year, Decathlon-AG2R were on cloud nine after the Giro. They took two stages and finished in fourth overall with Ben O’Connor. With two of the stars from last year’s roster off their books in 2025, the French squad were never going to surpass their results from twelve months ago.

That said, Nicolas Prodhomme managed to bring some champagne to the dinner table. The French climber, who only took his first pro win at the Tour of the Alps in April, enjoyed a solid Giro. Surfing in the teens in GC, Prodhomme managed to break free of the GC politics and claim a first Grand Tour stage victory on a tough day through the Valle d’Aosta on Stage 19.

Despite Prodhomme’s stage victory and eventual fifteenth place finish in GC, there will be some disappointment for the team’s sprint contingent. Sam Bennett had plenty of support, but the Munsterman would only reach the top ten of a sprint on one occasion over the three weeks. What he lacked in the sprints, Dries de Bondt picked up in the breakaway, claiming the lesser-known Intergiro prize.

EF Education-EasyPost: A

I can easily say that EF Education-First were one of the best teams at this year’s Giro d’Italia.

On the stage-winning front, the American team, which has nowhere near a superteam budget, exceeded expectations. Richard Carapaz and Kasper Asgreen took wins during the second week, with both affirming their big-money contracts over the past couple of seasons.

However, EF won’t be remembered for Asgreen’s breakaway effort. Instead, we will revisit Carapaz’s Stage 20 mind games. As the Ecuadorian failed to work with Del Toro on the Colle delle Finestre, his hopes of adding a second maglia rosa to his jersey collection went up in pink smoke. A second place turned into a third place, putting a bit of a downer on what had been an exceptional final week for the 2019 Giro champion.

Carapaz aside, EF played a bigger role in the race than some may have expected. Mikkel Honoré was back to his best, and Darren Rafferty, the first rider from the north of Ireland to ever compete in the Giro d’Italia, was an important domestique for Carapaz in the final week. Despite the squad’s relative lack of resources and manpower, they still managed to provide a solid GC bubble in support of Carapaz.

Groupama-FDJ: D

Many people had high hopes of Groupama-FDJ coming into this Giro. David Gaudu, a former top five finisher at the Tour de France, had finally made his Giro debut, and some hoped he would be able to shake off the lofty expectations of the French press now that he’d escaped the Grande Boucle. However, these hopes would soon disappear as Gaudu slipped down the GC pecking order.

Naturally, Groupama-FDJ then fulfilled their breakaway role. We got to know the likes of Enzo Paleni and Lorenzo Germani, while Gaudu and Rémy Rochas popped up when the road went uphill. In the end, there are no stage victories to discuss here, not even a top three placing.

There’s no secret that Groupama-FDJ will be looking forward to their home race in July. The Tour has always been a priority, with the Giro once again taking a second-tier role in the team’s results sheet. However, they really need to figure out how to win Giro stages, because it’s starting to become a bit of a mystery in the post-Pinot and Démare era.

Ineos Grenadiers: B

Ineos Grenadiers tried to reprise their role as an all-star GC team at this year’s Giro. Using their cast of young names, the squad were bullish in their quest for Egan Bernal to return top of the Grand Tour podium. In the end, these efforts would come up short as the Colombian finished in seventh place overall in his first Giro since winning the whole thing back in 2021.

You can’t accuse Ineos of not trying. During the second week they threw the kitchen sink at the peloton, trying to create a selection that could bring Bernal closer to the podium. Ultimately, the wheels fell off in the final week as Thymen Arensman ran out of steam and Bernal finally reached his limit.

However, some of the more notable results came outside of the mountains. Josh Tarling claimed his first Grand Tour time-trial in Albania, Ben Turner came close to a sprint win during the second week and Brandon Rivera continued to impress, particularly with his work on the gravel stage to Siena.

All things considered, a stage and top ten isn’t quite classic Ineos, but it’s certainly better than some other teams on this list and Bernal’s comeback is huge, even if he’s not at podium level yet.

Intermarché-Wanty: E

Intermarché have historically gone pretty well in the Giro. It’s where they claimed their first Grand Tour stage and GC top 10, and where we saw the birth of Biniam Girmay on the Grand Tour level. This year, however, all that legacy has circled the drain during three weeks of disappointment.

Taco van der Hoorn kept us entertained in the breakaways, with the familiar sight of his narrow handlebars, but ultimately he wouldn’t strike the jackpot through a lucky escape move. Louis Meintjes picked up the baton in the final week, but he would also struggle to stick around at the head of the race. Despite failing to find a winning move, the South African would eventually finish inside the top 20 of the GC standings, but that’s the only real bag of UCI points the Belgian team can write home about.

As the kids would say, Intermarché brought ‘a nothing burger’ to the picnic. They lacked any real substance and could have, quite frankly, stayed at home.

Israel-Premier Tech: B+

Israel-Premier Tech really relied on two figures during this Corsa Rosa: Derek Gee and Marco Frigo. Despite being a team of two playmakers, the team were able to score their biggest Giro result to date, with a top five courtesy of Canadian engine Gee.

Derek Gee was one of the strongest riders throughout the final week. He climbed up the ladder in the GC standings, eventually parking up in an impressive fourth place after the final mountain stage. With this result, Gee proved that the Tour last year was no one hit wonder and he may be able to target a Grand Tour podium in the near future.

Once again there were no stage victories for Israel-Premier Tech at this year’s Giro. That said, a fourth place on GC surely makes up for that.

Jayco AlUla: B+

With Ben O’Connor heading to the Tour de France with the team’s resident sprinter Dylan Groenwegen, Jayco brought their B team to the Giro d’Italia, headed up by Chris Harper in the GC. As the race unravelled, they fell out of overall standings, but luckily they evolved into one of the most notable teams in the breakaway.

In that role, they took two solo stage wins from Luke Plapp and Harper. Both have been knocking on the door of a big Grand Tour result for a couple of years now, so it’s good to see them finally rewarded, even if their achievements were overshadowed by the pink jersey battle behind.

They may not have achieved the GC result they had wished for going in but the Australian squad made the most of their situation. It’s not common for teams to win two stages from the breakaway in any Grand Tour, so we can only praise Jayco for pulling it off on two highly competitive days in the escape group.

Lidl-Trek: A

Lidl-Trek were one of the teams of the 2025 Giro d’Italia. They started in winning form, with Pedersen’s double in Albania during the opening days. This winning streak would only continue, with two further victories from Pedersen, a time-trial victory by Daan Hoole and one final breakaway victory for Carlos Verona. In total Lidl-Trek scored six stages, almost a third of the entire Giro.

Disappointingly Giulio Ciccone was wiped out of the GC following a crash on Stage 14. That was through no fault of his own because he was looking mightily strong beforehand, capable of reaching the top ten in GC at least if he stuck in the fight.

Overall though, this was an ideal Giro for Lidl-Trek. Yes, they missed out on the GC cherry, but Pedersen was the stand-out, proved by his maglia ciclamino tyranny. The team’s domestiques also shone, most notably Daan Hoole, Mathias Vacek and Carlos Verona. Everyone in the squad played their part, becoming some of the most familiar characters at this year’s Giro d’Italia.

It’ll be a tough ask for Jonathan Milan and Mattias Skjelmose to follow at the Tour de France, that’s for sure.

Movistar: C

Movistar were one of the least visible squads at this year’s Giro. They missed the sprints, many breakaways and kept a relatively low profile in the mountains. I’ll therefore keep this short and sweet.

Despite their relative lack of pizzazz, team leader Einer Rubio still managed to climb up the standings into the final top ten in Rome. He didn’t just scrape through either, he finished in eighth, not far off the much more visible Egan Bernal. Although there were no distinctive ‘wow moments’ from Movistar, this GC result certainly means the team were not left in the doldrums.

Picnic-PostNL: B

Picnic-PostNL needed to have a good Giro. They have been stalling so far in 2025, with victories few and far between. The Dutch team have, therefore, been dropping towards the relegation zone and have become locked in a tight battle between several lower-ranked teams.

Casper van Uden claimed a first Grand Tour stage victory early on in the race, supported greatly by a killer leadout from Bram Welten. Romain Bardet would face a worse fate, stumbling down the GC standings, only to then miss out on a stage win when we thought he’d have enough breakaway freedom to chase one final victory as a pro. Stages aside, the team were anchored by Max Poole’s GC yo-yo, eventually yielding a decent eleventh place in the overall standings. Not bad for an untested youngster.

In terms of the ongoing relegation battle, Picnic-PostNL stood their ground above the relegation zone, perhaps due to lacklustre performances from Cofidis and Intermarché. Van Uden’s stage win and Bardet’s runner-up spot helped prop up a healthy haul. It’s not been as successful as some of their Grand Tours before, but they did what they needed to squeeze out some sense of momentum for the races to come.

Polti-VisitMalta: C

Polti-VisitMalta are one of the few Italian wildcard teams to have won a stage in recent years. The Italian squad couldn’t add another stage this year, but they scored a couple of solid results in the sprints and breakaways. From the break, Mirco Maestri finished inside the top ten twice, as did sprinter Giovanni Lonardi. To top off these efforts, Davide Piganzoli pulled another solid GC result out the bag, finishing in fourteenth place overall.

Although this may not look all too impressive on paper, Polti received the sixth biggest prize money cheque from the race organisers at €58,183. Alessandro Tonelli alone scored roughly €12,000, not too far off Intermarché’s total for the entire race.

That said, Polti missed out on their precious Fuga prize, which is handed out to the rider with the most amount of breakaway kilometres. That aside, it was a solid Giro for the team part owned by former Giro champions Alberto Contador and Ivan Basso. Regardless of that near miss, Polti-VisitMalta were still one of the more visible teams in the breakaway, especially in the doomed escape groups on the flat. For this reason, I have to give them kudos for fulfilling the role the Italian invitees are often expected to fall into at the Giro. Maybe Q36.5 should take a note or two from their approach, but I’ll save that for later.

Q36.5: E

I think I speak for many when I say we had high expectations for Q36.5 on Grand Tour debut. Having beaten the likes of Uno X and the Italian Solutions squad to a wildcard spot, it was understandable for the Swiss team to be under a microscope for many.

On the road though, Tom Pidcock was incredibly disappointing throughout this Giro. Yes, he picked up a couple of top tens here and there, but he lacked any real chance in the GC. If you look at the final overall standings, he’s the lowest ranked out of the competitors who fully targeted the pink jersey coming into this race and weren’t blighted by crashes or breakaway snakes and ladders. I think this shows that Pidcock just isn’t cut out for GC. Some called this a practice run before the Vuelta, but I think this is categorical evidence that he needs to focus on stage wins and breakaways going forward.

Given that they were all-in for Project Pidcock, the team lacked any real stand-out performances from the breakaway. Matteo Moschetti provided some positive headlines in the sprints, but most of us were too busy criticising Pidcock to appreciate them.

Let’s hope the transfer news is true and Q36.5 start bolstering their roster, because if they get invited to next year’s Giro, I won’t be as lenient on their grade.

Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe: C

Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe came into the race with one of the strongest startlists. They boasted two former champions in Primož Roglič and Jai Hindley, and were supported by last year’s runner-up Dani Martínez and upcoming star Giulio Pelizzari. Their ambitions were sky high, with the victory a real possibility.

In reality, they were underwhelming for most of the race. Roglič’s buddies failed to control the race and then support him when he came down in several crashes and lost time. There was no sprinter to chase other top tens, so all hands were on board the sinking Slovenian ship, which would eventually run aground on Stage 16.

Interestingly, the team only got better once Roglič climbed into the car. Nico Denz salvaged a stage victory, while Guilin Pelizzari impressed throughout the final week, paving the way to an affirming sixth place overall. If it weren’t for these two riders’ results, Red Bull-Bora Hansgrohe would be firmly on a D or E grade.

Soudal-QuickStep: D

I’ve seen plenty of Grand Tours in my time. I’ve never seen one with such a poor performance from Soudal-QuickStep during all of its iterations.

To be fair, they were cruelly dealt a rough hand on day one when Mikel Landa was forced to abandon. As the team’s main priority and designated leader, some head scratching was required to get something out of the race.

James Knox made a brief GC bid, while Josef Černý and Mattia Cattaneo were sent out on breakaway duties, but Gianmarco Garofoli was the stand-out. The young Italian was a staple of the breakaways once the race hit the mountains. Although it didn’t lead to any stage victory, he deserves a big pat on the back for carrying the Belgian team’s race.

On the other hand, Paul Magnier received his first blow from Patrick Lefevere’s boxing glove of insults. He wasn’t convinced of Magnier’s Grand Tour debut, so don’t expect the Frenchman to be making a switch to the Tour de France anytime soon. Likewise, American sprinter Luke Lamperti was similarly off the mark, contrasting his early-season results in smaller competitions.

Tudor Pro Cycling: B

Tudor Pro Cycling will be riding two Grand Tours this year. This is quite rare for wildcard squads, so it can be hard for ProTeams to stand out over two separate Grand Tour rosters. New signings Marc Hirschi and Julian Alaphilippe have been handed a pass into the Tour de France, so it was down to Michael Storer and his band of young teammates to make it count here in Italy.

As expected, Storer once again finished inside the top ten. His GC result may not seem as ambitious as it once looked, but we have to factor in his waning form towards the final week of the race. At times, it looked as though he had the legs for better, but some crashes and off-days moved him down a couple of pegs in the overall standings.

Elsewhere, Florian Stork was a bit of a revelation at this year’s Giro, as he has been over the course of the 2025 season. Yannis Voisard was equally impressive, flying off in the breakaway on several occasions. The Swiss squad’s lead-out train looked first class at points, but there were only two top tens from Maikel Zijlaard to show for these efforts.

Overall, I look forward to what they bring at the Tour, but going forward, they really need better fortunes in Grand Tours if they want to compete for a WorldTour license at the end of the next cycle in 2028.

UAE Team Emirates XRG: A

It’s hard to judge UAE Team Emirates XRG’s Giro d’Italia. They managed to win two stages, the white jersey and finish in second place in GC, however they ultimately lost the race through strange tactics on the final stage to Sestriere.

Isaac del Toro ended up as the team leader after a tense two-pronged strategy during the second week. To that end, the squad lost the support of Juan Ayuso after cracking on Stage 16, then getting stung by a bee the following day. For Del Toro, on the other hand, this Grand Tour opened the door for an entertaining pink jersey bid. He claimed a stage and ruffled some feathers in the final week, riding like a Grand Tour champion.

As strong as Del Toro was, the team missed the opportunity to have satellite riders in the breakaway during the final week. Instead they nursed the chances of Brandon McNulty in the GC and kept Majka in the bunch to do the brunt of the work when they could have relied on rival squads. Many have raised criticism of UAE for playing this too defensively while Del Toro only had a minute’s advantage in the overall standings.

Regardless of how it all turned out, ten days in the pink jersey, two stages and a podium finish shouldn’t be overlooked. It feels subjective to say this but in terms of entertainment and getting us talking, UAE Team Emirates certainly overdelivered.

Visma-Lease a Bike: A

As traditional Grand Tour wish lists go, Visma-Lease a Bike ticked all the boxes. They won two sprint stages, the gravel stage and the overall classification. Clearly, it’s hard to pick flaws in their results sheet, given that they won on all terrains and claimed the biggest prize of them all.

Coming into the race with a split focus between Olav Kooij and Simon Yates, they ended up succeeding in both domains, especially once Van Aert clicked into gear on the gravel stage. The team were quite hands-off in the mountains, but Yates would soon lean on Van Aert to support him during the final week, not only in the valley after the Colle delle Finestre. These tactics were smart, relying on EF and UAE to set the pace and chase the breakaway during the final week, paving the way for a fresh Yates to pounce when it mattered.

Very few teams have mastered the art of balancing sprinting and GC in recent years. Not only that, but to the extent where you can win the GC and two sprint stages in the same year. For that, and bearing in mind the relatively weak startlist for Visma’-Lease a Bike’s standards, we can only say that they exceeded expectations in every sense.

XDS-Astana: A

As they have been for most of the year, XDS-Astana punched above their weight at the Giro d’Italia, an event they would consider to be their home race.

Through all the inevitable breakaway moves and top ten sprints, the performance that sticks in our minds has to be the one-two in San Valentino on Stage 16. There, early-season star Christian Scaroni added more UCI points to his growing haul as well as a first Grand Tour stage victory. We also can’t forget Diego Ulissi’s day in the maglia rosa, ending a ten-year wait to finally pull on the jersey.

In the end, XDS-Astana were the sixth-highest points scorers according to the UCI points scale. Their maglia azzura siege alone yielded over 300 points, the equivalent of a seventh place finish in GC, so they certainly managed to strike the jackpot in terms of their ongoing relegation fight. With a stage win along the way and a pink jersey stint, there’s not much more they could have asked for.

The post We graded every team’s 2025 Giro d’Italia appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Ewan Wilson | Staff Writer
